sub_topic: Find the volume form of a given metric.
message_1: Let $\mathrm{d}s^2 = (3x^2 + 2y^2)\mathrm{d}x^2 + 2xy\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y + (x^2 + y^2 + z^2)\mathrm{d}y^2 + \mathrm{d}z^2$ be a metric on $\mathbb{R}^3$. Find the volume form of this metric.
message_2:
To find the volume form of the given metric, we first need to compute the determinant of the metric tensor $g$. The metric tensor is given by:

$$
g = \begin{pmatrix}
3x^2 + 2y^2 & xy & 0 \\
xy & x^2 + y^2 + z^2 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{pmatrix}
$$

Now, we compute the determinant of $g$:

$$
\det(g) = \begin{vmatrix}
3x^2 + 2y^2 & xy & 0 \\
xy & x^2 + y^2 + z^2 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{vmatrix} = (3x^2 + 2y^2)((x^2 + y^2 + z^2)(1)) - (xy)^2(1) = (3x^2 + 2y^2)(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) - x^2y^2
$$

The volume form is given by the square root of the determinant of the metric tensor times the standard volume form in $\mathbb{R}^3$, which is $\mathrm{d}x \wedge \mathrm{d}y \wedge \mathrm{d}z$. Therefore, the volume form of the given metric is:

$$
\sqrt{\det(g)} \, \mathrm{d}x \wedge \mathrm{d}y \wedge \mathrm{d}z = \sqrt{(3x^2 + 2y^2)(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) - x^2y^2} \, \mathrm{d}x \wedge \mathrm{d}y \wedge \mathrm{d}z
$$
